0to%20over%20a%20century%20of%20anthropogenic%20change%20within%20a%20tidal%20marsh%20songbird%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Global%20Change%20Biology%2030%3Ae17126.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Spatial%20variation%20in%20population%20genomic%20responses%20to%20over%20a%20century%20of%20anthropogenic%20change%20within%20a%20tidal%20marsh%20songbird%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Phred%20M.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Benham%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Jennifer%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Walsh%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Rauri%20C.%20K.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Bowie%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Abstract%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Combating%20the%20current%20biodiversity%20crisis%20requires%20the%20accurate%20documentation%20of%20population%20responses%20to%20human%5Cu2010induced%20ecological%20change.%20However%2C%20our%20ability%20to%20pinpoint%20population%20responses%20to%20human%20activities%20is%20often%20limited%20to%20the%20analysis%20of%20populations%20studied%20well%20after%20the%20fact.%20Museum%20collections%20preserve%20a%20record%20of%20population%20responses%20to%20anthropogenic%20change%20that%20can%20provide%20critical%20baseline%20data%20on%20patterns%20of%20genetic%20diversity%2C%20connectivity%2C%20and%20population%20structure%20prior%20to%20the%20onset%20of%20human%20perturbation.%20Here%2C%20we%20leverage%20a%20spatially%20replicated%20time%20series%20of%20specimens%20to%20document%20population%20genomic%20responses%20to%20the%20destruction%20of%20nearly%2090%25%20of%20coastal%20habitats%20occupied%20by%20the%20Savannah%20sparrow%20%28%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Passerculus%20sandwichensis%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%29%20in%20California.%20We%20sequenced%20219%20sparrows%20collected%20from%201889%20to%202017%20across%20the%20state%20of%20California%20using%20an%20exome%20capture%20approach.%20Spatial%5Cu2013temporal%20analyses%20of%20genetic%20diversity%20found%20that%20the%20amount%20of%20habitat%20lost%20was%20not%20predictive%20of%20genetic%20diversity%20loss.%20Sparrow%20populations%20from%20southern%20California%20historically%20exhibited%20lower%20levels%20of%20genetic%20diversity%20and%20experienced%20the%20most%20significant%20temporal%20declines%20in%20genetic%20diversity.%20Despite%20experiencing%20the%20greatest%20levels%20of%20habitat%20loss%2C%20we%20found%20that%20genetic%20diversity%20in%20the%20San%20Francisco%20Bay%20area%20remained%20relatively%20high.%20This%20was%20potentially%20related%20to%20an%20observed%20increase%20in%20gene%20flow%20into%20the%20Bay%20Area%20from%20other%20populations.%20While%20gene%20flow%20may%20have%20minimized%20genetic%20diversity%20declines%2C%20we%20also%20found%20that%20immigration%20from%20inland%20freshwater%5Cu2010adapted%20populations%20into%20tidal%20marsh%20populations%20led%20to%20the%20erosion%20of%20divergence%20at%20loci%20associated%20with%20tidal%20marsh%20adaptation.%20Shifting%20patterns%20of%20gene%20flow%20through%20time%20in%20response%20to%20habitat%20loss%20may%20thus%20contribute%20to%20negative%20fitness%20consequences%20and%20outbreeding%20depression.%20Together%2C%20our%20results%20underscore%20the%20importance%20of%20tracing%20the%20genomic%20trajectories%20of%20multiple%20populations%20over%20time%20to%20address%20issues%20of%20fundamental%20conservation%20concern.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%2201%5C%2F2024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1111%5C%2Fgcb.17126%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%221354-1013%2C%201365-2486%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fonlinelibrary.wiley.com%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1111%5C%2Fgcb.17126%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T13%3A36%3A56Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%225LPSXU2N%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Bielski%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-01-31%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EBielski%2C%20L.%2C%20C.%20A.%20Cansler%2C%20K.%20McGinn%2C%20M.%20Z.%20Peery%2C%20and%20C.%20M.%20Wood%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fjournal.afonet.org%5C%2Fvol95%5C%2Fiss1%5C%2Fart4%5C%2F%27%3ECan%20the%20Hermit%20Warbler%20%28Setophaga%20occidentalis%29%20serve%20as%20an%20old-forest%20indicator%20species%20in%20the%20Sierra%20Nevada%3F%3C%5C%2Fa%3E%20Journal%20of%20Field%20Ornithology%2095.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Can%20the%20Hermit%20Warbler%20%28Setophaga%20occidentalis%29%20serve%20as%20an%20old-forest%20indicator%20species%20in%20the%20Sierra%20Nevada%3F%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Luca%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Bielski%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22C.%20Alina%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Cansler%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Kate%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22McGinn%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22M.%20Zachariah%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Peery%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Connor%20M.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Wood%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Changing%20fire%20regimes%20in%20western%20North%20America%20have%20raised%20the%20possibility%20of%20widespread%20loss%20of%20forest%20cover%2C%20making%20forest%20restoration%20a%20major%20priority.%20In%20one%20such%20ecosystem%2C%20the%20Sierra%20Nevada%20in%20California%2C%20the%20implications%20of%20forest%20management%20policy%20have%20been%20evaluated%20primarily%20via%20their%20potential%20effects%20on%20the%20California%20Spotted%20Owl%20%28Strix%20occidentalis%20occidentalis%29.%20Yet%20the%20owl%5Cu2019s%20cryptic%20life%20history%2C%20large%20home%20range%2C%20and%20declining%20population%20all%20make%20it%20difficult%20to%20study.%20The%20Hermit%20Warbler%20%28Setophaga%20occidentalis%29%20may%20be%20a%20valuable%20proxy%20species%20for%20the%20Spotted%20Owl%20because%20the%20two%20have%20similar%20associations%20with%20older%20forest%20habitat%2C%20but%20the%20former%20could%20enable%20researchers%20to%20achieve%20higher%20statistical%20power%20when%20studying%20changes%20to%20key%20habitats.%20We%20conducted%20passive%20acoustic%20surveys%20across%20the%20entire%20west%20slope%20of%20the%20Sierra%20Nevada%20between%20May%20and%20July%202021%2C%20identified%20both%20Hermit%20Warbler%20and%20Spotted%20Owl%20vocalizations%20in%20the%20resulting%20audio%20using%20the%20BirdNET%20algorithm%2C%20and%20used%20single-season%20occupancy%20models%20to%20examine%20the%20relationship%20between%20Hermit%20Warbler%20occupancy%20and%20six%20remotely%20sensed%20variables%20representing%20key%20attributes%20of%20older%20forests%20as%20well%20as%20Spotted%20Owl%20presence.%20Hermit%20Warblers%20were%20observed%20at%20all%20sites%20at%20which%20Spotted%20Owls%20were%20present%2C%20but%20those%20sites%20represented%20just%2030.5%25%20of%20the%20Hermit%20Warbler%5Cu2019s%20total%20occupied%20range.%20Hermit%20Warbler%20site%20occupancy%20was%20positively%20associated%20with%20mean%20tree%20diameter%20and%20the%20presence%20of%20Spotted%20Owls%20%28model%20weight%20%3D%200.97%29.%20The%20Hermit%20Warbler%20is%20more%20appropriate%20as%20a%20proxy%20for%20habitat%20beneficial%20to%20the%20California%20Spotted%20Owl%20than%20as%20a%20proxy%20for%20the%20owl%20itself.%20As%20such%2C%20monitoring%20and%20studying%20the%20Hermit%20Warbler%20could%20be%20a%20means%20of%20understanding%20the%20effects%20of%20forest%20restoration%20on%20important%20old-forest%20habitat.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%222024%5C%2F01%5C%2F31%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.5751%5C%2FJFO-00390-950104%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%221557-9263%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fjournal.afonet.org%5C%2Fvol95%5C%2Fiss1%5C%2Fart4%5C%2F%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T16%3A08%3A32Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%22XX2BMQMQ%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Blackburn%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-03-28%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EBlackburn%2C%20D.%20C.%2C%20D.%20M.%20Boyer%2C%20J.%20A.%20Gray%2C%20J.%20Winchester%2C%20J.%20M.%20Bates%2C%20S.%20L.%20Baumgart%2C%20E.%20Braker%2C%20D.%20Coldren%2C%20K.%20W.%20Conway%2C%20A.%20D.%20Rabosky%2C%20N.%20De%20La%20Sancha%2C%20et%20al.%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Facademic.oup.com%5C%2Fbioscience%5C%2Farticle%5C%2F74%5C%2F3%5C%2F169%5C%2F7615104%27%3EIncreasing%20the%20impact%20of%20vertebrate%20scientific%20collections%20through%203D%20imaging%3A%20The%20openVertebrate%20%28oVert%29%20Thematic%20Collections%20Network%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20BioScience%2074%3A169%5Cu2013186.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Increasing%20the%20impact%20of%20vertebrate%20scientific%20collections%20through%203D%20imaging%3A%20The%20openVertebrate%20%28oVert%29%20Thematic%20Collections%20Network%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22David%20C%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Blackburn%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Doug%20M%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Boyer%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22autho 0body%20shape%20diversification%20of%20a%20Gondwanan%20fish%20radiation%20%28Otophysi%3A%20Characiformes%29%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Evolution%2078%3A253%5Cu2013266.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22The%20role%20of%20abiotic%20and%20biotic%20factors%20in%20the%20unequal%20body%20shape%20diversification%20of%20a%20Gondwanan%20fish%20radiation%20%28Otophysi%3A%20Characiformes%29%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Michael%20D%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Burns%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Jason%20H%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Knouft%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Casey%20B%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Dillman%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22editor%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Eric%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Goolsby%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22editor%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Miriam%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Zelditch%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Abstract%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Understanding%20why%20some%20clades%20diversify%20greatly%20while%20others%20do%20not%20is%20a%20major%20goal%20of%20evolutionary%20biology.%20Both%20abiotic%20and%20biotic%20factors%20are%20important%20in%20driving%20unequal%20morphological%20diversity%20across%20the%20tree%20of%20life.%20However%2C%20few%20studies%20have%20quantified%20how%20abiotic%20habitat%20and%20community%20composition%20differences%20influence%20unequal%20morphological%20diversification%20in%20spatiotemporally%20diffuse%20radiations.%20We%20use%20geometric%20morphometrics%2C%20abiotic%20habitat%20data%20generated%20by%20Geographic%20Information%20Systems%20%28GIS%29%20analyses%2C%20evolutionary%20simulations%2C%20and%20phylogenetic%20comparative%20methods%20to%20determine%20whether%20random%20evolution%2C%20habitat%20variation%2C%20competition%20for%20niches%2C%20or%20a%20combination%20of%20factors%20influenced%20the%20u 0City%20to%20examine%20the%20influence%20of%20nocturnal%20weather%20conditions%20and%20bird%20migration%20traffic%20rates%20on%20collisions%20with%20buildings%20during%20spring%20and%20fall.%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%5CnWe%20found%20that%20seasonally%20unfavourable%20winds%20and%20conditions%20that%20impede%20visibility%20are%20important%20factors%20that%20increase%20the%20rates%20of%20bird%5Cu2013building%20collisions%20during%20both%20seasons.%20Specifically%2C%20northerly%20and%20westerly%20winds%20and%20low%20visibility%20in%20the%20spring%20and%20southerly%20and%20westerly%20winds%20and%20low%20cloud%20ceiling%20height%20in%20the%20fall%20are%20associated%20with%20higher%20collision%20risks.%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%5CnGenerally%2C%20these%20weather%20variables%20associated%20most%20strongly%20with%20increased%20collisions%20when%20nocturnal%20bird%20migration%20traffic%20was%20high%2C%20with%20the%20exception%20of%20low%20visibility%20in%20spring%2C%20which%20was%20predicted%20to%20triple%20collision%20rates%20compared%20to%20high%20visibility%2C%20independent%20of%20bird%20migration%20traffic.%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%5CnSynthesis%20and%20applications%3A%20Although%20legislation%20to%20turn%20off%20unnecessary%20nocturnal%20lighting%20for%20the%20entirety%20of%20the%20migration%20seasons%20may%20be%20an%20ultimate%20goal%2C%20a%20proximate%20goal%20invaluable%20for%20reducing%20collisions%20will%20be%20predicting%20which%20nights%20will%20be%20of%20highest%20risk%20and%20using%20this%20information%20to%20determine%20when%20mitigation%20efforts%20could%20be%20most%20effective.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%2204%5C%2F2024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1111%5C%2F1365-2664.14590%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%220021-8901%2C%201365-2664%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fbesjournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1111%5C%2F1365-2664.14590%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQM mpetitive%20abilities%20of%20an%20individual%2C%20reducing%20the%20need%20for%20physically%20damaging%20confrontation.%20Body%20size%2C%20sex%2C%20age%2C%20relatedness%2C%20and%20ornamentation%20are%20important%20factors%20determining%20dominance%20across%20diverse%20taxa%20in%20intraspecific%20interactions.%20These%20traits%2C%20when%20perceptible%2C%20may%20serve%20as%20signals%20across%20species%20in%20guilds%20that%20have%20frequent%20interspecific%20interactions.%20Hummingbirds%20provide%20a%20tractable%20system%20to%20study%20such%20community%20dynamics%20due%20to%20their%20high%20frequency%20of%20interactions%2C%20variable%20ornamentation%2C%20diverse%20body%20sizes%2C%20fast%20metabolism%2C%20and%20large%20overlap%20in%20resource%20utilization.%20Even%20in%20this%20system%2C%20potential%20interactions%20between%20morphology%20and%20coloration%20are%20rarely%20accounted%20for%20together%20when%20analyzing%20dominance%20between%20species.%20We%20take%20a%20novel%20approach%20to%20understanding%20interspecific%20dominance%20by%20assessing%20behavior%2C%20morphology%2C%20and%20coloration%20across%20different%20types%20of%20behavioral%20interactions.%20Across%2011%20tropical%20montane%20hummingbird%20species%2C%20we%20find%20that%20dominance%20is%20predicted%20by%20wing%20size%20and%20some%20metrics%20of%20plumage%20coloration.%20However%2C%20the%20biological%20significance%20of%20these%20factors%20varies%20between%20the%20different%20dominance%20behaviors%20performed.%20These%20results%20inform%20our%20understanding%20of%20interspecific%20signaling%20and%20its%20role%20in%20the%20evolution%20of%20intraguild%20communication%20and%20resource%20competition.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%2201%5C%2F2024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1111%5C%2Feth.13410%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%220179-1613%2C%201439-0310%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fonlinelibrary.wiley.com%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1111%5C%2Feth.13410%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22WZ6EF9QJ%22%2C%22PQMMSR8B%22%5 erto%20Rican%20Nightjars%20%28Guabairo%3B%20%3Ci%3EAntrostomus%20noctitherus%3C%5C%2Fi%3E%29%20on%20the%20Cabo%20Rojo%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Journal%20of%20Caribbean%20Ornithology%2037%3A12%5Cu201317.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Apparent%20range%20expansion%20or%20recolonization%20of%20Puerto%20Rican%20Nightjars%20%28Guabairo%3B%20%3Ci%3EAntrostomus%20noctitherus%3C%5C%2Fi%3E%29%20on%20the%20Cabo%20Rojo%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Leanne%20A.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Grieves%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Quinlan%20M.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Mann%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Michael%20J.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Morel%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22James%20S.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Quinn%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Abstract%5Cu00a0%20%5Cn%5Cn%5CnThe%20Puerto%20Rican%20Nightjar%20%28Guabairo%2C%20Antrostomus%20noctitherus%29%20is%20an%20Endangered%20bird%20species%20endemic%20to%20Puerto%20Rico.%20Typically%20inhabiting%20subtropical%20dry%20and%20lower%20montane%20forests%2C%20the%20species%20is%20currently%20rare%20to%20locally%20common%20from%20the%20southwest%20coast%20eastward%20to%20Guayama.%20However%2C%20based%20on%20the%20most%20recent%20population%20modeling%20from%202010%20and%20individual%20observations%20made%20by%20community%20members%2C%20nightjars%20may%20be%20more%20abundant%20and%20widely%20distributed%20than%20previously%20known.%20Consistent%20with%20this%2C%20during%20November%20and%20December%202021%2C%20we%20observed%20at%20least%20two%20Puerto%20Rican%20Nightjars%20on%20the%20Cabo%20Rojo%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%20in%20southwestern%20Puerto%20Rico%2C%20where%20the%20species%20has%20not%20been%20previously%20reported.%20Given%20the%20presence%20of%20this%20species%20in%20nearby%20areas%20of%20the%20Cabo%20Rojo%20municipality%20%28e.g.%2C%20in%20Punta%20Melones%29%2C%20our%20observations%20suggest%20a%20range%20expansion%20or%20recolonization%2C%20and%20could%20reflect%20an%20increase%20in%20species%20abundance.%20Targeted%20population%20monitoring%20and%20spatial%20tracking%20of%20the%20Puerto%20Rican%20Nightjar%20are%20needed%20to%20enable%20more%20robust%20population%20estimates%20that%20will%20inform%20future%20evaluations%20of%20this%20endangered%20endemic%5Cu2019s%20conservation%20status.%20We%20further%20recommend%20additional%20land%20protection%20measures%20to%20safeguard%20suitable%20nightjar%20breeding%20habitat%20in%20the%20Cabo%20Rojo%20region.%5Cn%5Cn%5CnKeywords%20%5Cn%5Cn%5CnAntrostomus%20noctitherus%2C%20Caprimulgidae%2C%20Endangered%20species%2C%20Puerto%20Rican%20Nightjar%2C%20Puerto%20Rico%2C%20range%20expansion%5Cn%5Cn%5CnResumen%5Cn%5Cn%5CnExpansi%5Cu00f3n%20aparentedel%20%5Cu00e1rea%20de%20distribuci%5Cu00f3n%20o%20recolonizaci%5Cu00f3n%20del%20Guabairo%20puertorrique%5Cu00f1o%20%28Antrostomus%20noctitherus%29%20en%20el%20Refugio%20Nacional%20de%20Vida%20Silvestre%20de%20Cabo%20Rojo%20%5Cu2022%20El%20Guabairo%20puertorrique%5Cu00f1o%20%28Antrostomus%20noctitherus%29%20es%20una%20especie%20de%20ave%20end%5Cu00e9mica%20de%20Puerto%20Rico%20en%20peligro%20de%20extinci%5Cu00f3n.%20Generalmente%20habita%20en%20bosques%20subtropicales%20secos%20y%20montanos%20bajos%20y%20en%20la%20actualidad%20se%20considera%20una%20especie%20rara%20o%20localmente%20com%5Cu00fan%20desde%20la%20costa%20suroeste%20hacia%20el%20este%20hasta%20Guayama.%20Sin%20embargo%2C%20seg%5Cu00fan%20el%20modelo%20de%20poblaci%5Cu00f3n%20m%5Cu00e1s%20reciente%20de%202010%20y%20las%20observaciones%20individuales%20realizadas%20por%20miembros%20de%20la%20comunidad%2C%20los%20guabairos%20podr%5Cu00edan%20ser%20m%5Cu00e1s%20abundantes%20y%20estar%20m%5Cu00e1s%20ampliamente%20distribuidos%20de%20lo%20que%20se%20conoc%5Cu00eda%20anteriormente.%20En%20consonancia%20con%20esto%2C%20durante%20noviembre%20y%20diciembre%20de%202021%2C%20observamos%20al%20menos%20dos%20guabairos%20puertorrique%5Cu00f1os%20en%20el%20Refugio%20Nacional%20de%20Vida%20Silvestre%20de%20Cabo%20Rojo%20en%20el%20suroeste%20de%20Puerto%20Rico%2C%20donde%20la%20especie%20no%20hab%5Cu00eda%20sido%20reportada%20previamente.%20Dada%20la%20presencia%20de%20esta%20especie%20en%20%5Cu00e1reas%20cercanas%20del%20municipio%20Cabo%20Rojo%20%28por%20ejemplo%2C%20en%20Punta%20Melones%29%2C%20nuestras%20observaciones%20sugieren%20una%20expansi%5Cu00f3n%20del%20%5Cu00e1rea%20de%20distribuci%5Cu00f3n%20o%20recolonizaci%5Cu00f3n%2C%20y%20podr%5Cu00edan%20reflejar%20un%20aumento%20en%20su%20abundancia.%20Se%20necesitan%20monitoreos%20poblacionales%20dirigidos%20y%20seguimientos%20espaciales%20del%20Guabairo%20puertorrique%5Cu00f1o%20para%20tener%20estimaciones%20poblacionales%20m%5Cu00e1s%20robustas%20que%20sirvan%20de%20base%20para%20evaluaciones%20futuras%20del%20estado%20de%20conservaci%5Cu00f3n%20de%20esta%20especie%20end%5Cu00e9mica%20en%20peligro%20de%20extinci%5Cu00f3n.%20Adem%5Cu00e1s%2C%20recomendamos%20medidas%20adicionales%20de%20protecci%5Cu00f3n%20del%20territorio%20para%20salvaguardar%20el%20h%5Cu00e1bitat%20adecuado%20para%20la%20reproducci%5Cu00f3n%20de%20A.%20noctitherus%20en%20la%20regi%5Cu00f3n%20de%20Cabo%20Rojo.%5Cn%5Cn%5CnPalabras%20clave%5Cn%5Cn%5CnAntrostomus%20noctitherus%2C%20Caprimulgidae%2C%20especie%20en%20peligro%20de%20extinci%5Cu00f3n%2C%20expansi%5Cu00f3n%20del%20%5Cu00e1rea%20de%20distribuci%5Cu00f3n%2C%20Guabairo%20puertorrique%5Cu00f1o%2C%20Puerto%20Rico%5Cn%5Cn%5Cn%5Cu00a0%5Cn%5Cn%5CnR%5Cu00e9sum%5Cu00e9%20%5Cn%5Cn%5CnExpansion%20de%20l%5Cu2019aire%20de%20r%5Cu00e9partition%20ou%20recolonisation%20apparente%20de%20l%5Cu2019Engoulevent%20de%20Porto%20Rico%20%28Guabairo%20%3B%20Antrostomus%20noctitherus%29%20dans%20le%20Cabo%20Rojo%20National%20Wildlife%20Refuge%20%5Cu2022%20L%5Cu2019Engo e%22%3A%22Leanne%20A.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Grieves%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Allyson%20L.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Brady%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Gregory%20F.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Slater%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22James%20S.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Quinn%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Gregarious%20species%20must%20distinguish%20group%20members%20from%20nongroup%20members.%20Olfaction%20is%20important%20for%20group%20recognition%20in%20social%20insects%20and%20mammals%20but%20rarely%20studied%20in%20birds%2C%20despite%20birds%20using%20olfaction%20in%20social%20contexts%20from%20species%20discrimination%20to%20kin%20recognition.%20Olfactory%20group%20recognition%20requires%20that%20groups%20have%20a%20signature%20odor%2C%20so%20we%20tested%20for%20preen%20oil%20and%20feather%20chemical%20similarity%20in%20group-living%20smooth-billed%20anis%20%28Crotophaga%20ani%29.%20Physiology%20affects%20body%20chemistry%2C%20so%20we%20also%20tested%20for%20an%20effect%20of%20egg-laying%20competition%2C%20as%20a%20proxy%20for%20reproductive%20status%2C%20on%20female%20chemical%20similarity.%20Finally%2C%20the%20fermentation%20hypothesis%20for%20chemical%20recognition%20posits%20that%20host-associated%20microbes%20affect%20host%20odor%2C%20so%20we%20tested%20for%20covariation%20between%20chemicals%20and%20microbiota.%20Group%20members%20were%20more%20chemically%20similar%20across%20both%20body%20regions.%20We%20found%20no%20chemical%20differences%20between%20sexes%2C%20but%20females%20in%20groups%20with%20less%20egg-laying%20competition%20had%20more%20similar%20preen%20oil%2C%20suggesting%20that%20preen%20oil%20contains%20information%20about%20reproductive%20status.%20There%20was%20no%20overall%20covariation%20between%20chemicals%20and%20microbes%3B%20instead%2C%20subsets%20of%20microbes%20could%20mediate%20olfactory%20cues%20in%20birds.%20Preen%20oil%20and%20feather%20chemicals%20showed%20little%20overlap%20and%20may%20contain%20different%20information.%20This%20is%20the%20first%20demonstration%20of%20group%20chemical%20signatures%20in%20birds%2C%20a%20finding%20of%20particular%20interest%20given%20that%20smooth-billed%20anis%20live%20in%20nonkin%20breeding%20groups.%20Behavioral%20experiments%20are%20needed%20to%20test%20whether%20anis%20can%20distinguish%20group%20members%20from%20nongroup%20members%20using%20odor%20cues.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%222024-04%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1086%5C%2F729221%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%220003-0147%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fwww.journals.uchicago.edu%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1086%5C%2F729221%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22WZ6EF9QJ%22%2C%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T15%3A52%3A17Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%22W6IL4D9N%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Harrison%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-04-23%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EHarrison%2C%20M.%20E.%2C%20N.%20J.%20Deere%2C%20M.%20A.%20Imron%2C%20D.%20Nasir%2C%20Adul%2C%20H.%20A.%20Asti%2C%20J.%20Aragay%20Soler%2C%20N.%20C.%20Boyd%2C%20S.%20M.%20Cheyne%2C%20S.%20A.%20Collins%2C%20L.%20J.%20D%27Arcy%2C%20et%20al.%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fwww.pnas.org%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1073%5C%2Fpnas.2307216121%27%3EImpacts%20of%20fire%20and%20prospects%20for%20recovery%20in%20a%20tropical%20peat%20forest%20ecosystem%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Proceedings%20of%20the%20National%20Academy%20of%20Sciences%20121%3Ae2307216121.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Impacts%20of%20fire%20and%20prospects%20for%20recovery%20in%20a%20tropical%20peat%20fo on%20and%20restoration%20goals.%20A%20poor%20understanding%20of%20the%20impacts%20of%20fire%20on%20ecosystems%20and%20their%20biodiversity%20exacerbates%20this%20challenge%2C%20particularly%20in%20tropical%20regions%20where%20few%20studies%20have%20applied%20consistent%20analytical%20techniques%20to%20examine%20a%20broad%20range%20of%20ecological%20impacts%20over%20multiyear%20time%20frames.%20We%20compiled%2016%20y%20of%20data%20on%20ecosystem%20properties%20%2817%20variables%29%20and%20biodiversity%20%2821%20variables%29%20from%20a%20tropical%20peatland%20in%20Indonesia%20to%20assess%20fire%20impacts%20and%20infer%20the%20potential%20for%20recovery.%20Burned%20forest%20experienced%20altered%20structural%20and%20microclimatic%20conditions%2C%20resulting%20in%20a%20proliferation%20of%20nonforest%20vegetation%20and%20erosion%20of%20forest%20ecosystem%20properties%20and%20biodiversity.%20Compared%20to%20unburned%20forest%2C%20habitat%20structure%2C%20tree%20density%2C%20and%20canopy%20cover%20deteriorated%20by%2058%20to%2098%25%2C%20while%20declines%20in%20species%20diversity%20and%20abundance%20were%20most%20pronounced%20for%20trees%2C%20damselflies%2C%20and%20butterflies%2C%20particularly%20for%20forest%20specialist%20species.%20Tracking%20ecosystem%20property%20and%20biodiversity%20datasets%20over%20time%20revealed%20most%20to%20be%20sensitive%20to%20recurrent%20high-intensity%20fires%20within%20the%20wider%20landscape.%20These%20megafires%20immediately%20compromised%20water%20quality%20and%20tree%20reproductive%20phenology%2C%20crashing%20commercially%20valuable%20fish%20populations%20within%203%20mo%20and%20driving%20a%20gradual%20decline%20in%20threatened%20vertebrates%20over%209%20mo.%20Burned%20forest%20remained%20structurally%20compromised%20long%20after%20a%20burn%20event%2C%20but%20vegetation%20showed%20some%20signs%20of%20recovery%20over%20a%2012-y%20period.%20Our%20findings%20demonstrate%20that%2C%20if%20left%20uncontrolled%2C%20fire%20may%20be%20a%20pervasive%20threat%20to%20the%20ecological%20functioning%20of%20tropical%20forests%2C%20underscoring%20the%20importance%20of%20fire%20prevention%20and%20long-term%20restoration%20efforts%2C%20as%20exemplified%20in%20Indonesia.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%222024-04-23%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1073%5C%2Fpnas.2307216121%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%22%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fwww.pnas.org%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1073%5C%2Fpnas.2307216121%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22WZ6EF9QJ%22%2C%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T16%3A11%3A16Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%222ZKTPVWQ%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Hedwig%20and%20Kohlberg%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-03-18%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EHedwig%2C%20D.%2C%20and%20A.%20Kohlberg%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fjournals.plos.org%5C%2Fplosone%5C%2Farticle%3Fid%3D10.1371%5C%2Fjournal.pone.0299656%27%3ECall%20combination%20in%20African%20forest%20elephants%20Loxodonta%20cyclotis%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20PLOS%20ONE%2019%3Ae0299656.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Call%20combination%20in%20African%20forest%20elephants%20Loxodonta%20cyclotis%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Daniela%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Hedwig%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Anna%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Kohlberg%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Syntax%2C%20the%20combination%20of%20meaning-devoid%20phonemes%20into%20meaningful%20words%2C%20which%20in%20turn%20are%20combined%20in%20structurally%20and%20semantically%20complex%20sentences%2C%20is%20fundamental%20to%20the%20unlimited%20expressiveness%20of%20human%20languages.%20Studying%20the%20functions%20of%20call%20combinations%20in%20non-human%20species%20provides%20insights%20into%20the%20evolution%20of%20such%20syntactic%20capabilities.%20Here%2C%20we%20investigated%20the%20combination%20of%20high%20amplitude%20broadband%20calls%20with%20low%20frequency%20rumble%20vocalizations%20in%20a%20highly%20social%20species%2C%20the%20African%20forest%20elephant%20Loxodonta%20cyclotis.%20Rumbles%20play%20an%20integral%20role%20in%20coordinating%20social%20interactions%20by%20transmitting%20socially%20relevant%20information%2C%20including%20individual%20identity.%20By%20contrast%2C%20broadband%20calls%2C%20such%20as%20roars%2C%20are%20thought%20to%20function%20as%20signals%20of%20distress%20and%20urgency%20as%20they%20are%20typically%20produced%20in%20situations%20of%20high%20emotional%20intensity.%20Functional%20changes%20associated%20with%20the%20combination%20of%20these%20calls%20remain%20little%20understood.%20We%20found%20that%20call%20combinations%20were%20produced%20by%20all%20age-sex%20classes%20but%20were%20most%20prevalent%20in%20immature%20individuals.%20We%20found%20that%20rumbles%20used%20singularly%20occurred%20in%20all%20five%20investigated%20social%20contexts%2C%20whereas%20single%20broadband%20calls%20were%20restricted%20to%20two%20resource-related%20contexts.%20Call%20combinations%20also%20occurred%20in%20all%20five%20contexts%2C%20suggesting%20an%20increase%20in%20the%20functional%20use%20of%20broadband%20calls%20when%20combined%20with%20rumbles%2C%20analogous%20to%20the%20generativity%20brought%20about%20through%20syntax%20in%20human%20speech.%20Moreover%2C%20combining%20calls%20appeared%20to%20lead%20to%20functional%20shifts%20towards%20high-stake%20contexts.%20Call%20combinations%20were%20more%20likely%20in%20competition%20contexts%20compared%20to%20single%20rumbles%2C%20and%20more%20likely%20in%20separation%20contexts%20compared%20to%20single%20broadband%20calls.%20We%20suggest%20that%20call%20combination%20in%20forest%20elephants%20may%20aide%20to%20reduce%20message%20ambiguity%20in%20high-stake%20situation%20by%20simultaneously%20communicating%20distress%20and%20individual%20identity%2C%20which%20may%20be%20critical%20to%20secure%20access%20to%20resources%2C%20reduce%20the%20risk%20of%20injury%20and%20to%20reunite%20with%20or%20recruit%20the%20support%20of%20the%20family%20group.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%22Mar%2018%2C%202024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1371%5C%2Fjournal.pone.0299656%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%221932-6203%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fjournals.plos.org%5C%2Fplosone%5C%2Farticle%3Fid%3D10.1371%5C%2Fjournal.pone.0299656%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T16%3A08%3A32Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%22VY6UXCEQ%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Herman%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A0%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EHerman%2C%20R.%20W.%2C%20G.%20Clucas%2C%20J.%20Younger%2C%20J.%20Bates%2C%20B.%20Robinson%2C%20S.%20Reddy%2C%20J.%20Stepanuk%2C%20K.%20O%27Brien%2C%20K.%20Veeramah%2C%20and%20H.%20J.%20Lynch%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fonlinelibrary.wiley.com%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1111%5C%2Fmec.17282%27%3EWhole%20genome%20sequencing%20reveals%20stepping%5Cu2010stone%20dispersal%20buffered%20against%20founder%20effects%20in%20a%20range%20expanding%20seabird%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Molecular%20Ecology%2033%3Ae17282.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Whole%20genome%20sequencing%20reveals%20stepping%5Cu2010stone%20dispersal%20buffered%20against%20founder%20effects%20in%20a%20range%20expanding%20seabird%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B 0size%20and%20expanded%20its%20range%20south%20along%20the%20Western%20Antarctic%20Peninsula.%20Using%20whole%20genome%20sequencing%2C%20we%20analysed%20129%20gentoo%20penguin%20individuals%20across%2012%20colonies%20located%20at%20or%20near%20the%20southern%20range%20edge.%20Through%20a%20detailed%20examination%20of%20fine%5Cu2010scale%20population%20structure%2C%20admixture%2C%20and%20population%20divergence%2C%20we%20inferred%20that%20gentoo%20penguins%20historically%20dispersed%20rapidly%20in%20a%20stepping%5Cu2010stone%20pattern%20from%20the%20South%20Shetland%20Islands%20leading%20to%20the%20colonization%20of%20Anvers%20Island%2C%20and%20then%20the%20adjacent%20mainland%20Western%20Antarctica%20Peninsula.%20Recent%20southward%20expansion%20along%20the%20Western%20Antarctic%20Peninsula%20also%20followed%20a%20stepping%5Cu2010stone%20dispersal%20pattern%20coupled%20with%20limited%20post%5Cu2010divergence%20gene%20flow%20from%20colonies%20on%20Anvers%20Island.%20Genetic%20diversity%20appeared%20to%20be%20maintained%20across%20colonies%20during%20the%20historical%20dispersal%20process%2C%20and%20range%5Cu2010edge%20populations%20are%20still%20growing.%20This%20suggests%20large%20numbers%20of%20migrants%20may%20provide%20a%20buffer%20against%20founder%20effects%20at%20the%20beginning%20of%20colonization%20events%20to%20maintain%20genetic%20diversity%20similar%20to%20that%20of%20the%20source%20populations%20before%20migration%20ceases%20post%5Cu2010divergence.%20These%20results%20coupled%20with%20a%20continued%20increase%20in%20effective%20population%20size%20since%20approximately%20500%5Cu2013800%5Cu2009years%20ago%20distinguish%20gentoo%20penguins%20as%20a%20robust%20species%20that%20is%20highly%20adaptable%20and%20resilient%20to%20changing%20climate.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%2203%5C%2F2024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1111%5C%2Fmec.17282%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%220962-1083%2C%201365-294X%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fonlinelibrary.wiley.com%5 Name%22%3A%22Daniel%20L.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Combs%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Bradley%20S.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Cohen%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22The%20spatiotemporal%20allocation%20of%20activity%20is%20fundamental%20to%20how%20organisms%20balance%20energetic%20intake%20and%20predation%20risk.%20Activity%20patterns%20fluctuate%20daily%20and%20seasonally%2C%20and%20they%20are%20proximately%20affected%20by%20exogenous%20and%20endogenous%20conditions.%20For%20birds%2C%20flight%20activity%20is%20often%20necessary%20for%20relocating%20between%20foraging%20patches%20but%20is%20energetically%20expensive%20and%20can%20increase%20mortality%20risk.%20Hunted%20species%20may%20have%20to%20adjust%20their%20behavior%20and%20activity%20patterns%20to%20minimize%20anthropogenic%20mortality%20risk.%20We%20used%20hourly%20locations%20from%20336%20GPS%5Cu2010marked%20mallards%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20Anas%20platyrhynchos%5Cn%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20%20to%20examine%20how%20hunting%20pressure%20affected%20flight%20activity%20in%20response%20to%20weather%20conditions%20and%20habitat%20availability%20during%20winter%20in%20western%20Tennessee%2C%20USA.%20Mallards%20were%20more%20likely%20to%20fly%20during%20crepuscular%20times%2C%20particularly%20dusk%2C%20across%20winter%20months.%20Mallards%20conducted%20more%20flights%20after%20shooting%20hours%20when%20habitat%20availability%20increased%20during%20open%20hunting%20season%3B%20conversely%2C%20mallard%20flights%20decreased%20with%20increasing%20habitat%20availability%20when%20hunters%20were%20present%20on%20the%20landscape.%20Mallards%20were%20least%20active%20during%20periods%20open%20to%20hunting.%20However%2C%20indicators%20of%20approaching%20inclement%20weather%20%28i.e.%20increased%20wind%20speed%2C%20precipitation%2C%20and%20decreasing%20barometric%20pressure%29%20increased%20flights%20during%20periods%20open%20to%20hunting.%20Mallard%20flights%20decreased%20at%20lower%20temperatures%20except%20when%20hunting%20season%20was%20closed%2C%20wherein%20mallards%20increased%20nighttime%20flights.%20Flight%20activity%20was%20directly%20influenced%20by%20hunting%20disturbance%20which%20constrained%20when%20and%20how%20mallards%20reacted%20to%20environmental%20and%20habitat%20conditions.%20An%20understanding%20of%20the%20temporal%20shifts%20in%20waterfowl%20flight%20patterns%20can%20be%20used%20by%20natural%20resource%20managers%20to%20better%20manage%20stakeholder%20satisfaction%20and%20expectations.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%2203%5C%2F2024%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1002%5C%2Fwlb3.01198%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%221903-220X%2C%201903-220X%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fnsojournals.onlinelibrary.wiley.com%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2F10.1002%5C%2Fwlb3.01198%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-13T20%3A00%3A17Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%22MA26K8BK%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Hoekstra%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3EHoekstra%2C%20B.%2C%20W.%20Bouten%2C%20A.%20Dokter%2C%20H.%20Van%20Gasteren%2C%20C.%20Van%20Turnhout%2C%20B.%20Kranstauber%2C%20E.%20Van%20Loon%2C%20H.%20Leijnse%2C%20and%20J.%20Shamoun%26%23x2010%3BBaranes%20%282024%29.%20Fireworks%20disturbance%20across%20bird%20communities.%20Frontiers%20in%20Ecology%20and%20the%20Environment%2022%3Ae2694.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Fireworks%20disturbance%20across%20bird%20communities%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Bart%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Hoekstra%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorT s%20140%20colonies%20in%20the%20Atlantic%20coast%20of%20Patagonia.%20However%2C%20little%20is%20known%20about%20the%20demography%20and%20connectivity%20of%20inland%20populations.%20We%20aim%20to%20provide%20information%20on%20the%20connectivity%20of%20the%20largest%20freshwater%20colonies%20%28those%20from%20Nahuel%20Huapi%20Lake%29%20with%20the%20closest%20Pacific%20and%20Atlantic%20populations%20to%20evaluate%20if%20these%20freshwater%20colonies%20are%20receiving%20immigrants%20from%20the%20larger%20coastal%20populations.%20We%20sampled%20three%20geographic%20regions%20%28Nahuel%20Huapi%20Lake%20and%20the%20Atlantic%20and%20Pacific%20coasts%29%20and%20employed%20a%20reduced-representation%20genomic%20approach%20to%20genotype%20individuals%20for%20single-nucleotide%20polymorphisms%20%28SNPs%29.%20Using%20clustering%20and%20phylogenetic%20analyses%20we%20found%20three%20genetic%20groups%2C%20each%20corresponding%20to%20one%20of%20our%20sampled%20regions.%20Individuals%20from%20marine%20environments%20are%20more%20closely%20related%20to%20each%20other%20than%20to%20those%20from%20Nahuel%20Huapi%20Lake%2C%20indicating%20that%20the%20latter%20population%20constitutes%20the%20first%20freshwater%20Kelp%20Gull%20colony%20to%20be%20identified%20as%20an%20evolutionary%20significant%20unit%20in%20Patagonia.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%222024-4-18%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22en%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1371%5C%2Fjournal.pone.0301004%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%221932-6203%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fdx.plos.org%5C%2F10.1371%5C%2Fjournal.pone.0301004%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T13%3A36%3A56Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%22HBW6FXQ7%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Kleindorfer%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-02%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20tex 2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Victoria%20I.%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Austin%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Diane%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Colombelli-N%5Cu00e9grel%22%7D%5D%2C%22abstractNote%22%3A%22Vocal%20production%20learning%20%28the%20capacity%20to%20learn%20to%20produce%20vocalizations%29%20is%20a%20multidimensional%20trait%20that%20involves%20different%20learning%20mechanisms%20during%20different%20temporal%20and%20socioecological%20contexts.%20Key%20outstanding%20questions%20are%20whether%20vocal%20production%20learning%20begins%20during%20the%20embryonic%20stage%20and%20whether%20mothers%20play%20an%20active%20role%20in%20this%20through%20pupil-directed%20vocalization%20behaviors.%20We%20examined%20variation%20in%20vocal%20copy%20similarity%20%28an%20indicator%20of%20learning%29%20in%20eight%20species%20from%20the%20songbird%20family%20Maluridae%2C%20using%20comparative%20and%20experimental%20approaches.%20We%20found%20that%20%281%29%20incubating%20females%20from%20all%20species%20vocalized%20inside%20the%20nest%20and%20produced%20call%20types%20including%20a%20signature%20%5Cu201cB%20element%5Cu201d%20that%20was%20structurally%20similar%20to%20their%20nestlings%5Cu2019%20begging%20call%3B%20%282%29%20in%20a%20prenatal%20playback%20experiment%20using%20superb%20fairy%20wrens%20%28Malurus%20cyaneus%29%2C%20embryos%20showed%20a%20stronger%20heart%20rate%20response%20to%20playbacks%20of%20the%20B%20element%20than%20to%20another%20call%20element%20%28A%29%3B%20and%20%283%29%20mothers%20that%20produced%20slower%20calls%20had%20offspring%20with%20greater%20similarity%20between%20their%20begging%20call%20and%20the%20mother%5Cu2019s%20B%20element%20vocalization.%20We%20conclude%20that%20malurid%20mothers%20display%20behaviors%20concordant%20with%20pupil-directed%20vocalizations%20and%20may%20actively%20influence%20their%20offspring%5Cu2019s%20early%20life%20through%20sound%20learning%20shaped%20by%20maternal%20call%20tempo.%22%2C%22date%22%3A%222024-02%22%2C%22language%22%3A%22%22%2C%22DOI%22%3A%2210.1086%5C%2F728105%22%2C%22ISSN%22%3A%220003-0147%22%2C%22url%22%3A%22https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fwww.journals.uchicago.edu%5C%2Fdoi%5C%2Ffull%5C%2F10.1086%5C%2F728105%22%2C%22collections%22%3A%5B%22WZ6EF9QJ%22%2C%22PQMMSR8B%22%5D%2C%22dateModified%22%3A%222024-05-14T15%3A51%3A57Z%22%7D%7D%2C%7B%22key%22%3A%2267J8554B%22%2C%22library%22%3A%7B%22id%22%3A2804417%7D%2C%22meta%22%3A%7B%22creatorSummary%22%3A%22Lakdari%20et%20al.%22%2C%22parsedDate%22%3A%222024-05-01%22%2C%22numChildren%22%3A1%7D%2C%22bib%22%3A%22%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-bib-body%5C%22%20style%3D%5C%22line-height%3A%201.35%3B%20padding-left%3A%201em%3B%20text-indent%3A-1em%3B%5C%22%3E%5Cn%20%3Cdiv%20class%3D%5C%22csl-entry%5C%22%3ELakdari%2C%20M.%20W.%2C%20A.%20H.%20Ahmad%2C%20S.%20Sethi%2C%20G.%20A.%20Bohn%2C%20and%20D.%20J.%20Clink%20%282024%29.%20%3Ca%20href%3D%27https%3A%5C%2F%5C%2Fwww.sciencedirect.com%5C%2Fscience%5C%2Farticle%5C%2Fpii%5C%2FS1574954123004867%27%3EMel-frequency%20cepstral%20coefficients%20outperform%20embeddings%20from%20pre-trained%20convolutional%20neural%20networks%20under%20noisy%20conditions%20for%20discrimination%20tasks%20of%20individual%20gibbons%3C%5C%2Fa%3E.%20Ecological%20Informatics%2080%3A102457.%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%5Cn%3C%5C%2Fdiv%3E%22%2C%22data%22%3A%7B%22itemType%22%3A%22journalArticle%22%2C%22title%22%3A%22Mel-frequency%20cepstral%20coefficients%20outperform%20embeddings%20from%20pre-trained%20convolutional%20neural%20networks%20under%20noisy%20conditions%20for%20discrimination%20tasks%20of%20individual%20gibbons%22%2C%22creators%22%3A%5B%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Mohamed%20Walid%22%2C%22lastName%22%3A%22Lakdari%22%7D%2C%7B%22creatorType%22%3A%22author%22%2C%22firstName%22%3A%22Abdul%20Hamid%22%2C
